thread.title: Heartbroken family and friends pay tribute to young South Australian firefighter Daniel Page after he suddenly died in his sleep: 'A proper hero'
thread.title_full: Heartbroken family and friends pay tribute to young South Australian firefighter Daniel Page after he suddenly died in his sleep: 'A proper hero'

author: VNExplorer
title: Heartbroken family and friends pay tribute to young South Australian firefighter Daniel Page after he suddenly died in his sleep: 'A proper hero'
text:
Daniel 'Pagey' Page died in sleep on TuesdayLieutenant at Salisbury Country Fire Service READ MORE: Firefighter dies while battling Grose Vale house fire
Tributes have flooded in for a much-loved young firefighter who tragically passed away in his sleep.
Daniel ‘Pagey’ Page, a Lieutenant 2 at Salisbury Country Fire Service branch in South Australia, died on Tuesday – just days before Christmas.
The sad news was shared to Facebook by his workplace two days later, remembering him as ‘one of Salisbury’s greats’.
‘Daniel, or as we call him ‘Pagey’, joined Salisbury CFS in 2017 and we knew from day one he would go on to achieve great things,’ the post read.
Daniel ‘Pagey’ Page (pictured) died during his sleep on Tuesday evening, just days before Christmas
‘From the stories told, his amazing, kind and empathetic nature has touched many in the service and the patients he cared for as well as saved.’
‘Pagey always had time for everyone around him and was the first to put his hand up when someone needed help,’ it continued.
‘His favourite things in life were triple double macchiatos, exploring the countryside with friends and family, working on vehicles or his next project, working incredibly hard to achieve more and being part of SAAS (South Australian Ambulance Service) to help others.’
The South Australian man was a Lieutenant 2 at Salisbury Country Fire Service branch and also worked as an Ambulance Officer with the South Australian Ambulance Service
Messages of love and support flowed in the comments section of the tragic Facebook post with many of his co-workers sharing stories about the ‘special’ man
The young firefighter was the caretaker for truck 58 and was in the middle of fixing up a leaky master cylinder – which was completed in his honour by a friend.
‘You will be forever missed Pagey and the world was a much better place with you in it. Rest easy mate, we will take it from here,’ it read.
Working his way up the ranks from Firefighter, to Senior Firefighter and then Lieutenant 2, the much-loved local was also an Ambulance Officer with the South Australian Ambulance Service.
Mr Page was awarded a commendation for his work in evacuating residents of a nursing home on the River Murray during last year’s floods.
He was also set to receive his National Emergency Medal for his part in fighting the 2019-2020 bushfires.
Mr Page was in the middle of fixing up truck 58’s leaky master cylinder which was completed in his honour by a friend
Much-loved and excellent at his job, Mr Page was awarded a commendation for his work in evacuations during last year’s floods and was set to receive his National Emergency Medal for his part in fighting the 2019-2020 bushfires
Mr Page was an aspiring paramedic and had just been accepted to study at Flinders University.
The post garnered hundreds of reactions and comments with friends, family and locals sending messages of love and support for the South Australian man’s family.
‘Only the good die young….RIP, to a proper hero,’ one wrote.
Another added: ‘A truly amazing guy, always had a smile no matter the situation, always providing his crew support and a gentle nudge if needed. He will still be at the front guiding us through danger and looking down as a leader that he was.
‘Pagey was special, he always had time for a chat and a laugh, his quick wit, intelligence and people skills set him apart from the rest and his rise through the ranks was not unexpected.’
The young firefighter was described as a ‘truly amazing guy’ and a ‘proper hero’ for his contributions to the community
A third shared the story of the day he first met Mr Page, writing: ‘Met him when he came on board as an apprentice – crashed his car the night before his first day at work – still made it in to set a huge impression.
‘Grew into a young man, hugely generous with his time, set his goals on some worthy endeavours which speak volumes of him and his family.’
‘Such a loss to all lucky enough to have spent time with him,’ the co-worker added.
Several neighbouring fire stations also offered their condolences, changing the official account profile pictures to the ‘firefighter down’ emblem.
